HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 12. 1926

BLUE JAYS TO
PLAY TOMORROW
The Johns Hbpkins Blue
Jay Orchestra will play tomorrow at the C. E. Hall, following the St. John's game,
and later at the Belvedere
Hotel for the First Cotillon.
Much question has arisen on
this subject due to the advertising of the opening of the
so-called "Varsity Club" as
the new home of the "Blue
Jays."

The University Hatchet, student
publication of George Washington
University, claims to have the largest circulation of any college
weekly in the country. Its circulation is 5,500.

Published semi-weekly from October to June by the students of Johns
Hopkins University.

HISTORY REPEATS ITSELF
Last _\pril or May we called attention to the habit of a number of professors of keeping their classes after twenty minutes
-past the hour. We mentioned none by name, but, nevertheless,
- there was a perceptible improvement soon after our indictment.
However, the traditional absent-mindedness of the college
prof seems to get the better of him, despite his good intentions
and the NEWS-LETTER'S reminder, with the result that nearly
a score of the faculty have been conspicuous by their 'delinquency,
in this matter during October and November.
We do not believe that any professor exceeds his time as a
matter of premeditated policy; in fact, the Professor of European History has often been known to stop his lectures in the

Quite different is the relation between cigarettes and college in
South Dakota. There the income
from the cigarette tax is used for
the erection of new buildings at the
state colleges and universities. Last
year, through the use of this income, the state was enabled to build
a new library at the State Agricultural College and a physical training building at the Normal College.
*
*
.The honor system at Western
Reserve University, which had been
in effect since 1908, was recently
done away with by the faculty. In
their opinion, as well as that of the
student body, the system is a failure. As contrasts, at Washington
and Lee and Johns Hopkins, the
.system grows more popular and
more effective each year.

are offenders could make an effort to allow their students ample
time to get from one building to another.
This practice is not only unfair to students, but is also very
piquing to the instructor whose lecture is interrupted by the tardy
appearance of members of the class.

A WORD ABOUT THE BAND
We believe in giving credit where credit is due. In past
years the johns Hopkins band has always been a Safe topic of
conversation whenever we wanted to have a good laugh without going to the trouble of trying to recall the last after-dinner
joke we had heard. It was known among all attendants at
Hopkins games as the last word in disharmony, discord and
feebleness. It was a black sheep.
But this year it seems to have taken a lease on life. It
has increased -in size, and what is most amazing, it plays music. Whether the direct credit belongs to Charles MacElfresh,
its leader, or any other member of the band, we do not know,
but nevertheless we extend our congratulations to the entire
organization.
6
Keep it up. You'll help us to beat Maryland yet.

For the second time Helen
Wills, former national tennis champion, has won a place on the honor
roll at the University of Southern
California. At present Misg Wills
is a junior there.
0
The Junior Class election at Amherst was recently thrown out entirely by ate Student Council as being invalid. It was discovered that
political combinations had been
formed by several fraternities. Such
a combination is against the anticombine pledges required on all
ballots.

A new theory as to low grades
is offered by students of Colorado
Agricultural College. A drag on a
cigarette between classes, say the
students, furnishes them with a certain stimulus which helps them in
class work. A faculty regulation
prohibiting smoking on the campus
removed this stimulus and a general slump followed. Whether the
theory is true or not, the faculty
has offered to give it a trial and
has removed its restriction.

The University of Alberta Will
have an indoor rink by the middle
of December. It was built with
money raised by charging each student $3.00 extra fees. This will
continue each year until it is entirely paid for.

3Loaded Buses
Parker Duofold Again
Defies Breakage

WE'LL BEAT ST. JOHN'S

This test was made
with sanction and
cooperation of the
Yellow Truck and
CoachMfg.Co.(subsidiary oftheGeneral
Motors Corp.) makers of the three
double-deck passenger buses that ran
over the Parker Duofold Pen.

55

/
The stag at eve

While Fifth Ave. Crowds Marvel
AIN Parker Duofold's new Permanite barrel has withstood a test that
w_11 astounds the world.
First hurled from a 25-story hotel to
cement without damage; then dropped
3000. ft. from an aeroplane and picked up
unbroken; now run over by three New
York buses filled with 67 passengers each.
This weight of more than 11 tons per
bus failed to break the pen barrel.
And in this test, as in the two others,
when the cap was removed from this
black-tipped lacquer-red beauty the Duofold point wrote perfectly. A point guaranteed 25 years not only for mechanical
perfection but for wear!
Select your style of point and size of
barrel at any first rate pen counter. But
look with caution for the imprint of the
originator,"Geo.S.Parker—DUOFOLD."
Carry the genuine—win the world's
respect.

/V

THIS fellow missed out on a heavy date tonight
by the close margin of one phone-call. But
don't waste pity on him. He has his jimmypipe and a tidy red tin of Prince Albert ...
grand little pals in time of stress.
When that cool, comforting smoke comes
curling up the pipe-stem, troubles evanesce with
every puff. For P. A. is The National Joy
Smoke in fact as well as phrase. Cool as a
money-lender. Sweet as a check from home.
Fragrant as a pine-grove on a damp morning.

P. A. is sold everywhere in
tidy red tins, pound and half.
pound tin humidors, and
pound crystal-glass humidors
with sponge-moistener top.
And always with every bit
of bite and parch removed by
the Prince Albert process.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 12, 1926

K. A.'S RECEIVE $40 FINE
FOR INFRINGEMENT
Interfraternity

Board Rules
Fraternity

Against

The Kappa Alpha Fraternity was
fined forty dollars at the regular
meeting of the Interfraternity
Previously
Board on Monday.
Kappa Alpha was found guilty of
breaking the rushing agreement on
two counts.
After a lengthy discussion it was
decided not to consider the breaches
of the agreement separately, but to
levy the fine upon the fraternity's
misconduct as a whole. The fine
was felt by many to be excessive
and not in keeping with the low
fines that have been the custom of
the board in years past. The Interfraternity Board in establishing this
precedent of high fines felt that
such a course was necessary if the
power of the board was to be felt
in the regulation of the affairs of
the Greeks on the campus.
A new constitution, to take the
place of the one lost years ago. will
be offered for consideration at the
next meeting.

DORM DOINGS
All of the representatives to the
Board of Governors from the six
entries have finally been elected.
The residents are now waiting for
them to meet, elect their officers,
discuss the old familiar regulations
pertaining to the conduct of a gentleman, appoint chairmen for the
various committees, and the like, so
that they can really get down to
business and secure some current
literature for the reading tables in
the Commons 'Room. Considerable
thought should be given to the selection of a man for chairman of
the literary committee. Whoever is
elected chairman of the social committee would do well to see if there
is enough enthusiasm among the
residents to warrant a Thanksgiving dance. We would also like to
suggest that the chairman of the
house committee investigate the
promise of draperies for the Commons Room.
Donald Bonney, who was injured
recently when a gas tank exploded
in back of the Mechanical Engineering Building, was released from the
Johns Hopkins Hospital and returned to his home in Pittsburgh to
recuperate. When released, Bonney was still confined to crutches,
however, he is expected to resume
his work at the University in a
short while.

Rodgers As Coach

to give up the position on account

SENIOR CLASS DUES TO BE
$31.50
Amount to Be Divided Among Banquet,
Hullabaloo, and June Week

At a conference of the cabinet of
the Senior class last Tuesday it was
decided that the Senior class dues
for 1927 would be $31.50.
Of this sum $10.00 is appropriated for June Week, $18.00 for the
Hullabaloo, and $3.50 for the Senior Class Banquet. Any senior
whose dues are paid desiring to attend the .Tune Week functions will
be charged only $3.50 extra.
Members of the class who have
not paid their Junior dues will be
taxed $4.00 for, although the Junior dues were only $3.00, an additional charge of $1.00 has been
adopted for their tardy payment.
The cabinet wishes to issue warnrig to all seniors that, following
the time-honored custom, no pictures will be placed in the 1927
Hullabaloo except of those men
whose entire class dues are fully
paid.

PRODUCERS OF TI-US

but why choose your
life-work that way?

PUBLICaTION
Last Monday evening there was
a royal apple and water fight in one
of the entries. Some said it was
in honor of the representatives
elected to the Board of Governors
from that entry, sort of an election celebration. Several baskets
of over-ripe apples and an incalculable amount of water were consumed. Undoubtedly, it was the
best combat of its kind in the history of the dormitory. It was different from any other battle, in
that following the encounter everyone joined in cleaning up the mess.
A real feeling of fellowship was
promoted.
The arrangement of separate, independent entries in the dormitory
is excellent. The value of this system, an English one, was admirably
illustrated Monday evening. Residents in the other entries were not
only undisturbed by the apple affair
but were not even aware of it.

MOTOR OIL

Your oil is important.

OU'D laugh at a man w ho couldn't
make up his mind which colors to back.
But isn't that about the way a good many
men start out on their careers?
All through college the most important
study a man can select is himself— to find
out by self-analysis and experience what is
his particular aptitude and what work he
should get into after college.
It's a good rule to talk this over with the
faculty and with men out in industry to get
all the guidance you can in "finding yourself" — because your whole happiness and
effectiveness in your career is at stake.

the new home of the "Blue
Jays."

HISTORY REPEATS ITSELF
Last _\pril or May we called attention to the habit of a number of professors of keeping their classes after twenty minutes
-past the hour. We mentioned none by name, but, nevertheless,
- there was a perceptible improvement soon after our indictment.
However, the traditional absent-mindedness of the college
prof seems to get the better of him, despite his good intentions
and the NEWS-LETTER'S reminder, with the result that nearly
a score of the faculty have been conspicuous by their 'delinquency,
in this matter during October and November.
We do not believe that any professor exceeds his time as a
matter of premeditated policy; in fact, the Professor of European History has often been known to stop his lectures in the

Quite different is the relation between cigarettes and college in
South Dakota. There the income
from the cigarette tax is used for
the erection of new buildings at the
state colleges and universities. Last
year, through the use of this income, the state was enabled to build
a new library at the State Agricultural College and a physical training building at the Normal College.
*
*
.The honor system at Western
Reserve University, which had been
in effect since 1908, was recently
done away with by the faculty. In
their opinion, as well as that of the
student body, the system is a failure. As contrasts, at Washington
and Lee and Johns Hopkins, the
.system grows more popular and
more effective each year.

are offenders could make an effort to allow their students ample
time to get from one building to another.
This practice is not only unfair to students, but is also very
piquing to the instructor whose lecture is interrupted by the tardy
appearance of members of the class.

A WORD ABOUT THE BAND
We believe in giving credit where credit is due. In past
years the johns Hopkins band has always been a Safe topic of
conversation whenever we wanted to have a good laugh without going to the trouble of trying to recall the last after-dinner
joke we had heard. It was known among all attendants at
Hopkins games as the last word in disharmony, discord and
feebleness. It was a black sheep.
But this year it seems to have taken a lease on life. It
has increased -in size, and what is most amazing, it plays music. Whether the direct credit belongs to Charles MacElfresh,
its leader, or any other member of the band, we do not know,
but nevertheless we extend our congratulations to the entire
organization.
6
Keep it up. You'll help us to beat Maryland yet.

For the second time Helen
Wills, former national tennis champion, has won a place on the honor
roll at the University of Southern
California. At present Misg Wills
is a junior there.
0
The Junior Class election at Amherst was recently thrown out entirely by ate Student Council as being invalid. It was discovered that
political combinations had been
formed by several fraternities. Such
a combination is against the anticombine pledges required on all
ballots.

A new theory as to low grades
is offered by students of Colorado
Agricultural College. A drag on a
cigarette between classes, say the
students, furnishes them with a certain stimulus which helps them in
class work. A faculty regulation
prohibiting smoking on the campus
removed this stimulus and a general slump followed. Whether the
theory is true or not, the faculty
has offered to give it a trial and
has removed its restriction.

The University of Alberta Will
have an indoor rink by the middle
of December. It was built with
money raised by charging each student $3.00 extra fees. This will
continue each year until it is entirely paid for.

The stag at eve

While Fifth Ave. Crowds Marvel
AIN Parker Duofold's new Permanite barrel has withstood a test that
w_11 astounds the world.
First hurled from a 25-story hotel to
cement without damage; then dropped
3000. ft. from an aeroplane and picked up
unbroken; now run over by three New
York buses filled with 67 passengers each.
This weight of more than 11 tons per
bus failed to break the pen barrel.
And in this test, as in the two others,
when the cap was removed from this
black-tipped lacquer-red beauty the Duofold point wrote perfectly. A point guaranteed 25 years not only for mechanical
perfection but for wear!
Select your style of point and size of
barrel at any first rate pen counter. But
look with caution for the imprint of the
originator,"Geo.S.Parker—DUOFOLD."
Carry the genuine—win the world's
respect.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 12, 1926

K. A.'S RECEIVE $40 FINE
FOR INFRINGEMENT
Interfraternity

Board Rules
Fraternity

Against

The Kappa Alpha Fraternity was
fined forty dollars at the regular
meeting of the Interfraternity
Previously
Board on Monday.
Kappa Alpha was found guilty of
breaking the rushing agreement on
two counts.
After a lengthy discussion it was
decided not to consider the breaches
of the agreement separately, but to
levy the fine upon the fraternity's
misconduct as a whole. The fine
was felt by many to be excessive
and not in keeping with the low
fines that have been the custom of
the board in years past. The Interfraternity Board in establishing this
precedent of high fines felt that
such a course was necessary if the
power of the board was to be felt
in the regulation of the affairs of
the Greeks on the campus.
A new constitution, to take the
place of the one lost years ago. will
be offered for consideration at the
next meeting.

DORM DOINGS
All of the representatives to the
Board of Governors from the six
entries have finally been elected.
The residents are now waiting for
them to meet, elect their officers,
discuss the old familiar regulations
pertaining to the conduct of a gentleman, appoint chairmen for the
various committees, and the like, so
that they can really get down to
business and secure some current
literature for the reading tables in
the Commons 'Room. Considerable
thought should be given to the selection of a man for chairman of
the literary committee. Whoever is
elected chairman of the social committee would do well to see if there
is enough enthusiasm among the
residents to warrant a Thanksgiving dance. We would also like to
suggest that the chairman of the
house committee investigate the
promise of draperies for the Commons Room.
Donald Bonney, who was injured
recently when a gas tank exploded
in back of the Mechanical Engineering Building, was released from the
Johns Hopkins Hospital and returned to his home in Pittsburgh to
recuperate. When released, Bonney was still confined to crutches,
however, he is expected to resume
his work at the University in a
short while.

SENIOR CLASS DUES TO BE
$31.50
Amount to Be Divided Among Banquet,
Hullabaloo, and June Week

At a conference of the cabinet of
the Senior class last Tuesday it was
decided that the Senior class dues
for 1927 would be $31.50.
Of this sum $10.00 is appropriated for June Week, $18.00 for the
Hullabaloo, and $3.50 for the Senior Class Banquet. Any senior
whose dues are paid desiring to attend the .Tune Week functions will
be charged only $3.50 extra.
Members of the class who have
not paid their Junior dues will be
taxed $4.00 for, although the Junior dues were only $3.00, an additional charge of $1.00 has been
adopted for their tardy payment.
The cabinet wishes to issue warnrig to all seniors that, following
the time-honored custom, no pictures will be placed in the 1927
Hullabaloo except of those men
whose entire class dues are fully
paid.

PRODUCERS OF TI-US

but why choose your
life-work that way?

PUBLICaTION
Last Monday evening there was
a royal apple and water fight in one
of the entries. Some said it was
in honor of the representatives
elected to the Board of Governors
from that entry, sort of an election celebration. Several baskets
of over-ripe apples and an incalculable amount of water were consumed. Undoubtedly, it was the
best combat of its kind in the history of the dormitory. It was different from any other battle, in
that following the encounter everyone joined in cleaning up the mess.
A real feeling of fellowship was
promoted.
The arrangement of separate, independent entries in the dormitory
is excellent. The value of this system, an English one, was admirably
illustrated Monday evening. Residents in the other entries were not
only undisturbed by the apple affair
but were not even aware of it.

MOTOR OIL

Your oil is important.

OU'D laugh at a man w ho couldn't
make up his mind which colors to back.
But isn't that about the way a good many
men start out on their careers?
All through college the most important
study a man can select is himself— to find
out by self-analysis and experience what is
his particular aptitude and what work he
should get into after college.
It's a good rule to talk this over with the
faculty and with men out in industry to get
all the guidance you can in "finding yourself" — because your whole happiness and
effectiveness in your career is at stake.
